ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by human activity. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:anthropogenic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation from magma Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:igneous_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation of magma at or immediately adjacent to Earth's surface. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:igneous_extrusive_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation of magma either in the open air or immediately adjacent to the land surface. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:subaerial_extrusive_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation of magma under water or ice. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:subaqueous_extrusive_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation of magma within the Earth. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:igneous_intrusive_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by crystallisation of magma far enough below Earth surface that complete crystallization of magma bodies forms holocrystalline medium to coarse grained igneous rock, wall rocks generally do not include volcanic products related to the magma, and some contact metamorphism is developed at intrusive contacts. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:plutonic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formed by crystallisation close to the Earth's surface, characterized by more rapid cooling than plutonic setting to produce generally fine-grained intrusive igneous rock, commonly associated with co-magmatic volcanic rocks. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:hypabyssal_intrusive_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by the physical, chemical or biological alteration of rock or sediment at or near the Earth surface; connotes involvement of processes related to the atmosphere (weather...). Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:weathering_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by processes of erosion, mass wasting, transportation, deposition, precipitation and biogenic production that take place in Earth’s hydrosphere and atmosphere. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:sedimentary_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by accumulation of particles (clasts) derived by weathering, erosion, or fragmentation of pre-existing rock or produced by chemical or biologically-mediated precipitation. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:clastic_sedimentary_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by deposition of material produced by living organisms either as part of their body (e.g., exoskeleton, bone, pollen, wood) or through their activities (e.g., faecal pellets). Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:biological_sedimentary_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by direct chemical precipitation (e.g., evaporites, exhalative deposits). Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:chemical_sedimentary_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by chemical and physical changes subsequent to deposition of sediment, during and after lithification that occur under temperature and pressure conditions too low to be considered metamorphic. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:diagenetic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by changes in chemical, mineralogical, or structural properties of rocks in response to chemical and physical conditions that have been imposed below the surface zones of weathering and cementation (diagenesis), and that differ from the conditions under which the rocks in question originated. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metamorphic_metasomatic_or_hydrothermal_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by open-system changes in chemical composition by reaction with an external source, typically involving chemical transport by a fluid medium flowing through the rock. Metasomatism typically involves introduction of chemical constituents into a rock volume. Source: based on Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metasomatic_or_hydrothermal_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by closed-system changes in mineralogy, texture, or fabric of a rock in response to chemical and physical conditions that have been imposed below the surface zones of weathering and cementation (diagenesis), and that differ from the conditions under which the rocks in question originated. As defined here the changes in rock volume may include removal of some chemical constituents from the system (especially water and other volatile constituents). Note narrower use that Neuendorf et al. 2005; this vocabulary distinguishes metasomatism from metamorphism. Source: based on Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metamorphic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by metamorphism due to the effect of a magma body on the rocks it intrudes. Source: based on Smulikowski et al, 2003
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:contact_metamorphic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by metamorphic processes affecting a large rock volume, associated with large-scale tectonic processes. Source: Smulikowski et al, 2003
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:regional_metamorphic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by metamorphism that may be attributed to a localized cause, such as magmatic intrusion, faulting, metorite impact, combustion of naturally occuring substances (coal), or lightning. Source: Smulikowski et al, 2003
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:local_metamorphic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by metamorphism of local extent associated with fault zones or shear zones. 'Dislocation metamorphic genesis' is 'Deformation genesis' of local extent, explicitly associated with a particular fault or shear zone. Source: based on Smulikowski et al, 2003
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:dislocation_metamorphic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by strain-related processes resulting in changes of shape of a rock body, including folding, faulting, shearing, or fabric development; deformation may be either brittle or ductile. Local deformation metamorphic genesis related to a particular fault or shear zone is categorized as 'Dislocation metamorphic genesis' Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:deformation_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by deformation without loss of material continuity at the scale of observation. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:ductile_deformation_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by brittle deformation, i.e. the formation and growth of fractures and frictional sliding along fracture surfaces. Source: based on Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:cataclastic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation predominantly by metamorphism related to the passage of a shock wave through a body of material, typically the result of impact of a planetary body (impactor) on a planetary surface (target) Source: Smulikowski et al, 2003
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:impact_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation in which more than one genetic process is dominant. This usually involves some combination of igneous, weathering, sedimentary, metamorphic, deformation or impact-related processes that better represents the origin of the material Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:composite_process_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by a combination of igneous and sedimentary processes Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:igneous_sedimentary_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by a combination of extrusive igneous activity and sedimentary transport and deposition. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:volcaniclastic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by metamorphism of an igneous protolith Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metaigneous_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by metamorphism of an extrusive igneous protolith. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metavolcanic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by metamorphism of a plutonic igneous protolith. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metaplutonic_genesis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Formation by metamorphism of a sedimentary protolith. Source: this vocab
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:GeneticCategory:200811:metasedimentary_genesis
